elements.content: Polar chains built from acentric building units are of importance to investigate the mechanisms driving the polar alignment in the solid state. Our attempts to engineer polar chains in mixed metal oxide fluorides M′(2,2′-bpy)(H2O)2MO x F6–x compounds [M′/M = Cu/Ti, Cu/V, Cu/Nb, Cu/Mo, Zn/Mo, and Zn/W] were successful using a combination of acentric anions [MO x F6–x ]2– and acentric cations [M′(2,2′-bpy)(H2O)2]2+. A new general insight is also revealed: the alignment of polar units can be described with a “lock and key” model. The role of both the key (the acentric unit) and the lock (its environment) on the polarity in infinite chains is discussed.
elements.clean_text: Polar chains built from acentric building units are of importance to investigate the mechanisms driving the polar alignment in the solid state. Our attempts to engineer polar chains in mixed metal oxide fluorides M'(2,2'-bpy)(H2O)2MO x F6-x  compounds [M'/M = Cu/Ti, Cu/V, Cu/Nb, Cu/Mo, Zn/Mo, and Zn/W] were successful using a combination of acentric anions [MO x F6-x ]2- and acentric cations [M'(2,2'-bpy)(H2O)2]2+. A new general insight is also revealed: the alignment of polar units can be described with a "lock and key" model. The role of both the key (the acentric unit) and the lock (its environment) on the polarity in infinite chains is discussed.

elements.content: The “lock and key” model is used to describe the alignment of acentric units in infinite chains. The key (the polar unit) must match with the lock (the environment of the acentric unit) to optimize the polar alignment.
elements.clean_text: The "lock and key" model is used to describe the alignment of acentric units in infinite chains. The key (the polar unit) must match with the lock (the environment of the acentric unit) to optimize the polar alignment.

elements.content: Basic building units (BBUs) with individual net dipole moments are extensively used in either organic or inorganic solid-state chemistry for the engineering of new non-centrosymmetric materials with interesting properties (piezoelectricity, nonlinear optics, ferroelectricity, pyroelectricity, etc.). Different approaches have been reported in recent years, such as the alignment of acentric transition-metal complexes or lone pair cations. Nonetheless, these BBUs rarely lead to polar arrangement because of the poor control on their orientation within the bond network. An initial step toward the alignment of acentric units in three-dimensional (3D) crystal structure is to investigate polar chains built from these acentric BBUs. The polar alignment is facilitated in a one-dimensional (1D) chain in comparison to a 3D structure, and new general insights to design the non-centrosymmetry in the solid state can also be identified.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Basic building units (BBUs) with individual net dipole moments are extensively used in either organic or inorganic solid-state chemistry for the engineering of new non-centrosymmetric materials with interesting properties (piezoelectricity, nonlinear optics, ferroelectricity, pyroelectricity, etc.). Different approaches have been reported in recent years, such as the alignment of acentric transition-metal complexes or lone pair cations. Nonetheless, these BBUs rarely lead to polar arrangement because of the poor control on their orientation within the bond network. An initial step toward the alignment of acentric units in three-dimensional (3D) crystal structure is to investigate polar chains built from these acentric BBUs. The polar alignment is facilitated in a one-dimensional (1D) chain in comparison to a 3D structure, and new general insights to design the non-centrosymmetry in the solid state can also be identified.

elements.content: In oxyfluoride chemistry, early transition-metal (ETM)-centered anions with the formula [MO x F6–x ]2– (x = 1, M = V, Nb, and Ta; x = 2, M = Mo and W) exhibiting out-of-center distortion are key constituents for the engineering of polarity. The combination of a late transition-metal (LTM) cation with an ETM anion [MO x F6–x ]2– leads to mixed metal infinite chains. The architecture of these chains can be designed by the appropriate choice of ETM, LTM, and organic ligand. Thus, three different inorganic infinite chains are reported in the literature: the linear chain (trans-MX6 2– and M′L4 2+), the zigzag chain [trans-MX6 2– and M′(H2O)2L2 2+], and the helical chain [cis-MX6 2– and M′(H2O)2L2 2+] (M′ = LTM, M = ETM, X = O2–/F–, and L = ligand). However, none of the previously reported structures exhibits polar chains because of the orientational disorder of the polar anions or the anti-alignment of the individual dipole moments along the chain.
elements.clean_text: In oxyfluoride chemistry, early transition-metal (ETM)-centered anions with the formula [MO x F6-x ]2- (x = 1, M = V, Nb, and Ta; x = 2, M = Mo and W) exhibiting out-of-center distortion are key constituents for the engineering of polarity. The combination of a late transition-metal (LTM) cation with an ETM anion [MO x F6-x ]2- leads to mixed metal infinite chains. The architecture of these chains can be designed by the appropriate choice of ETM, LTM, and organic ligand. Thus, three different inorganic infinite chains are reported in the literature: the linear chain (trans-MX6 2- and M'L4 2+), the zigzag chain [trans-MX6 2- and M'(H2O)2L2 2+], and the helical chain [cis-MX6 2- and M'(H2O)2L2 2+] (M' = LTM, M = ETM, X = O2-/F-, and L = ligand). However, none of the previously reported structures exhibits polar chains because of the orientational disorder of the polar anions or the anti-alignment of the individual dipole moments along the chain.

elements.content: The engineering of the polarity in zigzag chains was assessed by creating an acentric local environment for the anions. Thus, acentric [M′(2,2′-bpy)(H2O)2]2+ LTM cations were designed using the 2,2′-bipyridine organic ligand. The analysis of the resulting structures points out the analogy between the polarity in infinite chains and the “lock and key” model. The design of the lock (the environment of the anion) is essential to create an alignment of net dipole moments, while the key (polar unit) must match with the lock to optimize the alignment.
elements.clean_text: The engineering of the polarity in zigzag chains was assessed by creating an acentric local environment for the anions. Thus, acentric [M'(2,2'-bpy)(H2O)2]2+ LTM cations were designed using the 2,2'-bipyridine organic ligand. The analysis of the resulting structures points out the analogy between the polarity in infinite chains and the "lock and key" model. The design of the lock (the environment of the anion) is essential to create an alignment of net dipole moments, while the key (polar unit) must match with the lock to optimize the alignment.

elements.content:
Materials

TiO2 (99.9%, Aldrich), V2O5 (99.6%, Aldrich), Nb2O5 (99.9%, Aldrich), MoO3 (99.95%, Alfa Aesar), WO3 (99.8%, Alfa Aesar), CuO (99%, Aldrich), ZnO (99.99%, Aldrich), 2,2′-bipyridyne (99%, Aldrich), and aqueous hydrofluoric acid (48% HF by weight, Aldrich) were used as received. Reagent amounts of deionized water were also used in the synthesis. Adding water before HF allows for the reduction of the exothermic effect of the hydrofluoric acid reacting with the organic.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Caution

  

Materials

TiO2 (99.9%, Aldrich), V2O5 (99.6%, Aldrich), Nb2O5 (99.9%, Aldrich), MoO3 (99.95%, Alfa Aesar), WO3 (99.8%, Alfa Aesar), CuO (99%, Aldrich), ZnO (99.99%, Aldrich), 2,2'-bipyridyne (99%, Aldrich), and aqueous hydrofluoric acid (48% HF by weight, Aldrich) were used as received. Reagent amounts of deionized water were also used in the synthesis. Adding water before HF allows for the reduction of the exothermic effect of the hydrofluoric acid reacting with the organic.

elements.content: Single crystals of compounds 1–6 have been synthesized by the hydrothermal method. All reagents were heat-sealed in a Teflon pouch and placed in a 125 mL Parr autoclave with a backfill of 45 mL of distilled water. The autoclave was heated to 150 °C for 24 h and slowly cooled to room temperature at 6 °C/h. The single crystals were recovered by filtration.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis

Single crystals of compounds 1-6 have been synthesized by the hydrothermal method. All reagents were heat-sealed in a Teflon pouch and placed in a 125 mL Parr autoclave with a backfill of 45 mL of distilled water. The autoclave was heated to 150 °C for 24 h and slowly cooled to room temperature at 6 °C/h. The single crystals were recovered by filtration.

elements.content: Cu(2,2′-bpy)(H2O)2TiF6 single crystals (1) were synthesized by adding 1.477 × 10–3 mol (0.118 g) of TiO2, 1.69 × 10–3 mol (0.134 g) of CuO, 2.56 × 10–3 mol (0.400 g) of 2,2′-bipyridyl, 5.5 × 10–3 mol (0.1 mL) of H2O, and 28.42 × 10–3 mol (1.16 g) of 48% HF to a Teflon pouch. Single crystals were recovered by vacuum filtration in air in a 60% yield based on Ti.

elements.content: Attempts to determine the structures of compounds Cu(2,2′-bpy)(H2O)2TaOF5 and Cu(2,2′-bpy)(H2O)2WO2F4 have been unsuccessful because of the poor quality of the crystals. However, the comparison of X-ray powder diffraction patterns confirms that the later compounds are isostructural to compounds 1–6. Attempts to synthesize the isostructural compounds Zn(2,2′-bpy)(H2O)2VOF5, Zn(2,2′-bpy)(H2O)2NbOF5, and Zn(2,2′-bpy)(H2O)2TaOF5 have been unsuccessful.

Attempts to synthesize the isostructural compounds Zn(2,2'-bpy)(H2O)2VOF5, Zn(2,2'-bpy)(H2O)2NbOF5, and Zn(2,2'-bpy)(H2O)2TaOF5 have been unsuccessful.

elements.content: Single-crystal diffraction experiments were conducted at 100 K using a Bruker-APEX II charge-coupled device (CCD) diffractometer with monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.710 69 Å). The crystal–detector distance was 60 mm, and data integrations were made using the SAINT-PLUS program. Absorption corrections have been processed using SADABS. The structures were determined by means of direct methods, completed by Fourier difference syntheses using SIR97, and then refined using SHELXL-97. Additional symmetry elements were checked using the program PLATON. Hydrogen atoms of 2,2′-bipyridine molecules were constrained to ride at distances of 0.93 Å from the associated C atoms with U iso(H) = 1.5U eq(C). The large positive residual density (11.03 eA–3) in compound 6 is close to the tungsten atom. Crystallographic data are reported in Table .
elements.clean_text:
Crystallographic Determination

Single-crystal diffraction experiments were conducted at 100 K using a Bruker-APEX II charge-coupled device (CCD) diffractometer with monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71069 Å). The crystal-detector distance was 60 mm, and data integrations were made using the SAINT-PLUS program. Absorption corrections have been processed using SADABS. The structures were determined by means of direct methods, completed by Fourier difference syntheses using SIR97, and then refined using SHELXL-97. Additional symmetry elements were checked using the program PLATON. Hydrogen atoms of 2,2'-bipyridine molecules were constrained to ride at distances of 0.93 Å from the associated C atoms with U iso(H) = 1.5U eq(C). The large positive residual density (11.03 eA-3) in compound 6 is close to the tungsten atom. Crystallographic data are reported in Table .

The mixed metal oxide fluoride compounds 1–6 are isostructural and crystallize in the centrosymmetric space group Pnma. Zig-zag chains built from alternating [MO x F6–x ]2– anions and [M′(2,2′-bpy)(H2O)2]2+ cations propagate along the a axis (see ). The chains stack through hydrogen bonding to create the 3D structures. For compounds 1–4, the Jahn–Teller distortion of [Cu(2,2′-bpy)(H2O)2]2+ cations propagates along the chains. The distortion of [MO x F6–x ]2– anions differs for compounds 1–6.
elements.clean_text:
Results

Structural Description

The mixed metal oxide fluoride compounds 1-6 are isostructural and crystallize in the centrosymmetric space group Pnma. Zig-zag chains built from alternating [MO x F6-x ]2- anions and [M'(2,2'-bpy)(H2O)2]2+ cations propagate along the a axis (see ). The chains stack through hydrogen bonding to create the 3D structures. For compounds 1-4, the Jahn-Teller distortion of [Cu(2,2'-bpy)(H2O)2]2+ cations propagates along the chains. The distortion of [MO x F6-x ]2- anions differs for compounds 1-6.

elements.content: In the search of new polar materials in organic or inorganic solid-state chemistry, most approaches report the alignment of acentric units. Hence, different strategies use acentric metal–ligand complexes or lone pair cations. For each strategy, the authors usually describe the interactions between the polar BBUs and the extended structure and point out the importance to align the BBUs along the polar axis to optimize the net dipole moment of the materials. Nonetheless, no rationalization of the interactions between the acentric units and their environment has been reported thus far. In this paper, we rationalize the system “extended structure and polar BBU” with the model “lock and key”. This model is extensively used in biology to describe the mechanism in which enzymes attach to the molecules. In a similar way, the alignment of the polar BBUs is optimized when the right “key” (polar BBU) is used for the right “lock” (the environment of polar BBU).
elements.clean_text:
Discussion

"Lock and Key" Model

In the search of new polar materials in organic or inorganic solid-state chemistry, most approaches report the alignment of acentric units. Hence, different strategies use acentric metal-ligand complexes or lone pair cations. For each strategy, the authors usually describe the interactions between the polar BBUs and the extended structure and point out the importance to align the BBUs along the polar axis to optimize the net dipole moment of the materials. Nonetheless, no rationalization of the interactions between the acentric units and their environment has been reported thus far. In this paper, we rationalize the system "extended structure and polar BBU" with the model "lock and key". This model is extensively used in biology to describe the mechanism in which enzymes attach to the molecules. In a similar way, the alignment of the polar BBUs is optimized when the right "key" (polar BBU) is used for the right "lock" (the environment of polar BBU).

elements.content: Owing to the off-centering of the ETMs in [MO x F6–x ]2– anions, individual net dipole moments are generated. The distortion is induced by the electronic effects, such as dπ–pπ metal oxide orbital interactions (primary distortion) and the interactions between the [MO x F6–x ]2– anion and its environment (secondary distortion).
elements.clean_text:
"Key": Nature and Properties of [MO x F6-x ]2- Acentric Units

Owing to the off-centering of the ETMs in [MO x F6-x ]2- anions, individual net dipole moments are generated. The distortion is induced by the electronic effects, such as dπ-pπ metal oxide orbital interactions (primary distortion) and the interactions between the [MO x F6-x ]2- anion and its environment (secondary distortion).

elements.content: One condition to align the individual net dipole moment is to prevent a complete orientational disorder of the polar [MO x F6–x ]2– anions. If the disorder occurs, the net dipole moment is canceled and the structure cannot be polar. To identify the presence of orientational disorder, one must be able to distinguish oxide and fluoride. However, the identity of the ligand cannot be directly distinguished by X-ray crystallography because of similar structure factors. A comparison of metal–ligand bond lengths allows for their identification. For [MO x F6–x ]2– anions, the MO bond lengths are typically shorter than the M–F bond, owing to dπ–pπ metal oxide orbital interactions. Moreover, the M–F bonds in trans position of MO are usually longer than other M–F bonds. From a crystallographic viewpoint, the orientational disorder results in equivalent metal–ligand bond lengths.

However, the identity of the ligand cannot be directly distinguished by X-ray crystallography because of similar structure factors. A comparison of metal-ligand bond lengths allows for their identification. For [MO x F6-x ]2- anions, the MO bond lengths are typically shorter than the M-F bond, owing to dπ-pπ metal oxide orbital interactions. Moreover, the M-F bonds in trans position of MO are usually longer than other M-F bonds. From a crystallographic viewpoint, the orientational disorder results in equivalent metal-ligand bond lengths.

elements.content: The coordination of [MO x F6–x ]2– anions to the extended bond network differ according to the nucleophilicities of O2–/F– ligands. For [VOF5]2– and [MoO2F4]2– anions, the oxide ligands are less nucleophilic than fluoride ligands because of the strong dπ–pπ metal oxide orbital interactions. The off-centering of the transition metal toward the oxide also makes the trans fluoride more nucleophilic than the other ligands. For these reasons, [VOF5]2– and [MoO2F4]2– are cis-directing anions. [MoO2F4]2– bonds strongly to the structure through the fluoride ligands trans to the oxide, while [VOF5]2– usually bonds strongly to the structure through the fluoride ligand trans to the oxide and one of the equatorial ligands. [WO2F4]2– has been reported to be either cis- or trans-directing anions because the oxide ligands, which are more nucleophilic than the oxides in [MoO2F4]2–, can bond to the extended structure. In the other hand, [NbOF5]2– and [TaOF5]2– are trans-directing anions because they direct the coordination through the nucleophilic oxide and its trans fluoride.

[MoO2F4]2- bonds strongly to the structure through the fluoride ligands trans to the oxide, while [VOF5]2- usually bonds strongly to the structure through the fluoride ligand trans to the oxide and one of the equatorial ligands. [WO2F4]2- has been reported to be either cis- or trans-directing anions because the oxide ligands, which are more nucleophilic than the oxides in [MoO2F4]2-, can bond to the extended structure. In the other hand, [NbOF5]2- and [TaOF5]2- are trans-directing anions because they direct the coordination through the nucleophilic oxide and its trans fluoride.

elements.content: While the individual net dipole moments are intrinsic of the polar units, their alignment or anti-alignment in the solid state depends only upon their environments. Thus, the design of the environment of polar units (the “lock”) is essential to create polar materials.
elements.clean_text:
Design the "Lock" To Align the Acentric Units

While the individual net dipole moments are intrinsic of the polar units, their alignment or anti-alignment in the solid state depends only upon their environments. Thus, the design of the environment of polar units (the "lock") is essential to create polar materials.

elements.content: In oxyfluoride chemistry, mixed metal chains can be designed into either linear, zigzag, or helical chains. In our previous work, the architecture of these chains was shown to depend upon the interaction between ETM, LTM, and organic ligand. The design of the linear chains requires a trans-directing ETM-centered anion and a LTM coordinated to four organic ligands in equatorial positions (Figure a). The design of the zigzag chains requires trans-directing ETM-centered anion and LTM coordinated to two organic ligands in trans position. The LTM completes its coordination environment with two water molecules in trans position. Owing to this relative position of water molecules, intrachain hydrogen interactions between the hydrogen atoms of these water molecules and the oxide/fluoride ligands of the ETM-centered anions occur and induce the zigzag geometry (Figure b). The design of the helical chains requires a cis-directing ETM-centered anion. The combination of these anions with trans-directing LTM induces the crystallization of 31 or 32 helices (Figure c). The presence of helices with an unique handedness was shown to be responsible of the chirality in these later structures.

The LTM completes its coordination environment with two water molecules in trans position. elements.content: Despite the good control on the design of these three different chains, the individual net dipole moments of the anions could not be aligned thus far. In linear chains, the polar anions are either disordered or ordered in opposite direction along the chains. Orientational disorder occurs in zigzag chains, while the individual polarities are perpendicular to the screw axis and also cancel each other in helical chains (Figure ). Zigzag mixed metal chains are also interesting because no example of ordered anions was reported up to now. The ordering of the anions into a polar manner was also assessed to create polar, zigzag chains.

The ordering of the anions into a polar manner was also assessed to create polar, zigzag chains.

elements.content: The first condition to align acentric units is to prevent the complete orientational disorder around its position. The orientational disorder occurs when the coordinations of ligands in trans position are equivalent, i.e., when the anion is centered in a local inversion center. Thus, the orientation of the acentric units toward one direction or the opposite one is equivalent. In the long range, the orientation is averaged to zero and the anion is orientationally disordered. In the previously reported zigzag chains, the bonding of trans ligands is equivalent: two trans ligands are bound to equivalent LTM, and the four equatorial ligands create equivalent hydrogen bonding with the water ligands of the LTM.

The orientational disorder occurs when the coordinations of ligands in trans position are equivalent, i.e., when the anion is centered in a local inversion center. Thus, the orientation of the acentric units toward one direction or the opposite one is equivalent. In the long range, the orientation is averaged to zero and the anion is orientationally disordered. In the previously reported zigzag chains, the bonding of trans ligands is equivalent: two trans ligands are bound to equivalent LTM, and the four equatorial ligands create equivalent hydrogen bonding with the water ligands of the LTM.

elements.content: To “break” the local centrosymmetry around the polar anion, the bonding of trans ligands must be distinguished from each other. The bondings of trans ligands connected to the LTM cannot be distinguished without modifying the chain. For this reason, our work focused on modifying the bonding of the four equatorial ligands. In the previously reported structures, equivalent hydrogen bonding between equatorial ligands of the ETM and the water ligand of the LTM was induced by the trans position of the water ligands in the environment of the LTM (Figure ). To create a non-centrosymmetric environment for the ETM anions, one can modify the coordination of the LTM cations to avoid water molecules in trans position. The relative position of water molecules can be predicted by controlling the relative position of organic ligands. Thus, bidentate ligands, such as 2,2′-bipyridyne, must coordinate the LTM in a cis position, and consequently, the water molecules complete the coordination in a cis configuration. This strategy lead to the partial or complete alignment of the anions in compounds 1–6 (Figure ). The hydrogen atoms of water ligands bond selectively to some ligands of the ETM and not the trans ligands. The hydrogen bond network is also focused on the most nucleophilic ligands of the ETM anion, which align in the same direction to create the polar zigzag chains.

elements.content: In structures 1–6, both ordering and alignment occur, owing to the propagation of acentric anions and acentric cations. As previously reported, the combination of two acentric units anion/anion or cation/anion, when interacting together, tends to create non-centrosymmetric arrangement. This observation can be rationalized on the basis of the analysis of the inorganic chains in compounds 1–6. In the case of a unique polar unit AB, two possibilites can occur: the interactions AB–AB are stabilized and lead to the alignment of net dipole moments (Figure a), or the interactions AB–BA are stabilized and lead to the anti-alignment of net dipole moments (Figure b). The crystallization in either polar or nonpolar chain is very difficult to predict because it requires the knowledge of the interactions between AB units. However, when one acentric unit A′B′ is used in combination with the polar unit AB, two cases can occur: the interactions AB–A′B′ are stabilized and lead to the alignment of net dipole moments (Figure c), or the interactions AB–B′A′ are stabilized and also lead to the alignment of net dipole moments (Figure d). The combination of the two different acentric units will also more likely lead to a non-centrosymmetric arrangement than the use of only one polar unit. In the case of a combination of polar units with centrosymmetric units, the orientational disorder of units AB will likely occur (Figure e). Thus, the previously reported zigzag chains with centrosymmetric LTM cations exhibit orientational disorder of polar ETM anions.

elements.content: In the compounds 1–6, the polar chains anti-aligned into centrosymmetric arrangements, owing to interchain hydrogen bonding and π–π stacking (see ). The polar chain of these structures can be considered as a unique 1D acentric unit, which can also pack following the arrangement described in Figure a. Two possibilities could also be considered to generate a non-centrosymmetric arrangement in the 3D framework: (i) considering two zero-dimensional (0D) acentric units, which interact in the 3D framework, such as (Ag3MoO3F3)(Ag3MoO4)Cl, or (ii) designing two 1D acentric units, which interact in the 3D framework.

elements.content: The physical properties induced by the polarity are dependent upon the arrangement of polar units in the material. Thus, the second harmonic generation (SHG) response can be evaluated using Chen’s anionic group theory, which has proven to be successful with the discovery of different nonlinear (NLO) borates, such as KBe2BO3F2 or Sr2Be2B2O7. According to this theory, the SHG response is optimized when the spatial arrangement of anionic groups with spontaneous polarization is maximized. To find crystal structures where the polar axes of anionic groups are parallel to each other, a structural criterion C can be derived as follows: C = | ∑ i = 1 n p i | n where n is the number of anionic groups and p is defined by p = ∑ i e R i − ∑ j e ′ r j | ∑ i e R i − ∑ j e ′ r j | In the point charge model, e and e′ are the charges of cations and anions within the group and R and r are the site vectors. If the polar anions are oriented in parallel, the criterion C is equal to 1, but if they are oriented in opposite direction, it is equal to 0.
elements.clean_text:
Find the Right "Key" To Optimize the Alignment of Acentric Units

The physical properties induced by the polarity are dependent upon the arrangement of polar units in the material. Thus, the second harmonic generation (SHG) response can be evaluated using Chen's anionic group theory, which has proven to be successful with the discovery of different nonlinear (NLO) borates, such as KBe2BO3F2 or Sr2Be2B2O7. According to this theory, the SHG response is optimized when the spatial arrangement of anionic groups with spontaneous polarization is maximized. To find crystal structures where the polar axes of anionic groups are parallel to each other, a structural criterion C can be derived as follows:  C =   |   ∑   i = 1   n     p   i   |   n    where n is the number of anionic groups and  p  is defined by  p =     ∑   i   e   R   i   -   ∑   j   e '   r   j     |   ∑   i   e   R   i   -   ∑   j   e '   r   j   |    In the point charge model, e and e' are the charges of cations and anions within the group and  R  and  r  are the site vectors. If the polar anions are oriented in parallel, the criterion C is equal to 1, but if they are oriented in opposite direction, it is equal to 0.

elements.content: In compounds 1–6, the anions are either orientationally ordered or partially disordered (i.e., incomplete orientational disorder). When completely ordered, the anions are parallel and the criterion C is equal to 1 along the chain. However, the criterion C is lower than 1 if the anions are partially disordered because the individual dipole moments partially cancel each other. Figure reports the values of the criterion C according to the possible orientational order/disorder of the [MOF5]2– and [MO2F4]2– anions.
elements.clean_text: In compounds 1-6, the anions are either orientationally ordered or partially disordered (i.e., incomplete orientational disorder). When completely ordered, the anions are parallel and the criterion C is equal to 1 along the chain. However, the criterion C is lower than 1 if the anions are partially disordered because the individual dipole moments partially cancel each other. Figure  reports the values of the criterion C according to the possible orientational order/disorder of the [MOF5]2- and [MO2F4]2- anions.

elements.content: Structural criterion C for [MOF5]2– and [MO2F4]2– anions with different orientational disorder.
elements.clean_text: 4  Structural criterion C for [MOF5]2- and [MO2F4]2- anions with different orientational disorder.

elements.content: To describe the environment of anions (the “lock”), compound 1 is interesting because [TiF6]2– is an inherently non-distorted anion. Thus, the distortion is only secondary, i.e., only induced by the interactions between the anion and its environment. The investigation of bond distances allows for differentiation of the site of ligands. The ligands F1 are terminal, while the ligands F2, in trans position of F1, create strong hydrogen bonding. The ligands F3 and F4 create strong bonds with the LTM. Ti4+ is displaced toward the two terminal fluoride ligands (ligands F1). From this structure, the valence sum between each ligand and the extended structure can be calculated to classify the ligand site from the least to the most nucleophilic: Nw (the weakest nucleophilicity), Nm (moderate nucleophilicity), and Ns (the strongest nucleophilicity) (Table and Figure ). A hypothetical structure with LTM = Zn, instead of Cu, is also considered for the calculation of Zn–F valences (the Zn–F distances are estimated to be equal to the distances in compound 5). Owing to the absence of first-order Jahn–Teller distortion for Zn, the valence sum of ligands F3 and F4 coordinated to the LTM is higher. Thus, Figure represents what the anion should be to match its environment.

elements.content: In compound 2 and 4, the anions are oriented to create hydrogen bonding between the water ligands of the LTM and the most nucleophilic ligands of the ETM. The most nucleophilic ligands of [VOF5]2– and [MoO2F4]2– anions are the fluoride in trans position of the oxide ligands. The oxide ligands, which are the least nucleophilic, are also terminal, and the trans fluoride creates hydrogen bonding. In compound 4, [MoO2F4]2– exhibits two equivalent most nucleophilic fluoride ligands and is also completely ordered (Figure a). In compound 2, [VOF5]2– exhibits only one most nucleophilic fluoride ligand and is also partially disordered between two positions (Figure a). Contrary to the symmetrically similar [VOF5]2–, [NbOF5]2– anions of compound 3 exhibit a nucleophilic oxide ligand. Because both the oxide and the trans fluoride are nucleophlic ligands in [NbOF5]2–, the polarity of this anion can be oriented either along or perpendicular to the chain. Thus, [NbOF5]2– is partially disordered between three positions (Figure a).
elements.clean_text: In compound 2 and 4, the anions are oriented to create hydrogen bonding between the water ligands of the LTM and the most nucleophilic ligands of the ETM. The most nucleophilic ligands of [VOF5]2- and [MoO2F4]2- anions are the fluoride in trans position of the oxide ligands. The oxide ligands, which are the least nucleophilic, are also terminal, and the trans fluoride creates hydrogen bonding. In compound 4, [MoO2F4]2- exhibits two equivalent most nucleophilic fluoride ligands and is also completely ordered (Figure a). In compound 2, [VOF5]2- exhibits only one most nucleophilic fluoride ligand and is also partially disordered between two positions (Figure a). Contrary to the symmetrically similar [VOF5]2-, [NbOF5]2- anions of compound 3 exhibit a nucleophilic oxide ligand. Because both the oxide and the trans fluoride are nucleophlic ligands in [NbOF5]2-, the polarity of this anion can be oriented either along or perpendicular to the chain. Thus, [NbOF5]2- is partially disordered between three positions (Figure a).

elements.content: “Lock and key” representation of (a) compounds 2–4 with LTM = Cu and (b) compounds 5 and 6 with LTM = Zn. The alignment of the net dipole moment is optimized in the case of matching between the key (the polar anion) and the lock (its environment).
elements.clean_text: 6  "Lock and key" representation of (a) compounds 2-4 with LTM = Cu and (b) compounds 5 and 6 with LTM = Zn. The alignment of the net dipole moment is optimized in the case of matching between the key (the polar anion) and the lock (its environment).

elements.content: In compounds 5 and 6 with Zn2+ cations, the environment of the ETM anions is different. Owing to the absence of Jahn–Teller distortion of the LTM, the ligands bonding to Zn2+ must be more nucleophilic than the ligands bonding the Cu2+ cations in compounds 1–4. For this reason, the nucleophilic fluoride ligands trans of the oxide can be coordinated to either Zn2+ or the hydrogen atoms of the water ligand of the LTM. Thus, [MoO2F4]2– and [WO2F4]2– are partially disordered between three positions in compounds 5 and 6 (Figure b).
elements.clean_text: In compounds 5 and 6 with Zn2+ cations, the environment of the ETM anions is different. Owing to the absence of Jahn-Teller distortion of the LTM, the ligands bonding to Zn2+ must be more nucleophilic than the ligands bonding the Cu2+ cations in compounds 1-4. For this reason, the nucleophilic fluoride ligands trans of the oxide can be coordinated to either Zn2+ or the hydrogen atoms of the water ligand of the LTM. Thus, [MoO2F4]2- and [WO2F4]2- are partially disordered between three positions in compounds 5 and 6 (Figure b).

elements.content: In summary, the orientational ordering of anions is observed only in compound 4 because the [MoO2F4]2– anion perfectly matches its environment. In compounds 2, 3, 5, and 6, the discrepancy between the anions and their environment lead to a partial disorder. For this reason, the orientational ordering of the polar units can be described with the “lock and key” model. Three possibilities can be considered: (a) the key does not match with the lock, and consequently, the anion cannot crystallize in such an environment; our attempts to synthesize the compounds Zn(2,2′-bpy)(H2O)2VOF5, Zn(2,2′-bpy)(H2O)2NbOF5, and Zn(2,2′-bpy)(H2O)2TaOF5 have been unsuccessful; (b) the key does not match with the lock, and consequently, the anion is partially disordered (compounds 2, 3, 5, and 6); and (c) the key matches with the lock, and consequently, the anion is completely ordered and the alignment is fully optimized (compound 4). Different keys cannot match with the same lock, as illustrated with compounds 2, 3, and 4. Similarly, the same key cannot match with different locks, as illustrated with compounds 4 and 5.
elements.clean_text: In summary, the orientational ordering of anions is observed only in compound 4 because the [MoO2F4]2- anion perfectly matches its environment. In compounds 2, 3, 5, and 6, the discrepancy between the anions and their environment lead to a partial disorder. For this reason, the orientational ordering of the polar units can be described with the "lock and key" model. Three possibilities can be considered: (a) the key does not match with the lock, and consequently, the anion cannot crystallize in such an environment; our attempts to synthesize the compounds Zn(2,2'-bpy)(H2O)2VOF5, Zn(2,2'-bpy)(H2O)2NbOF5, and Zn(2,2'-bpy)(H2O)2TaOF5 have been unsuccessful; (b) the key does not match with the lock, and consequently, the anion is partially disordered (compounds 2, 3, 5, and 6); and (c) the key matches with the lock, and consequently, the anion is completely ordered and the alignment is fully optimized (compound 4). Different keys cannot match with the same lock, as illustrated with compounds 2, 3, and 4. Similarly, the same key cannot match with different locks, as illustrated with compounds 4 and 5.

elements.content: The “lock and key” model offers a good description of the polar arrangement of acentric BBUs in infinite chains. The lock (the environment of acentric BBU) must be designed properly to induce the alignment of the net dipole moment, and the key (the polar BBU) must match with the lock to optimize the alignment of the polar BBUs. A non-centrosymmetric environment for polar BBUs, suitable for the alignment of the net dipole moments, can be designed using an additional acentric unit. In the mixed metal oxide fluorides M′(2,2′-bpy)(H2O)2MO x F6–x [M′/M = Cu/Ti, Cu/V, Cu/Nb, Cu/Mo, Zn/Mo, and Zn/W] reported in this paper, the acentric [M′(2,2′-bpy)(H2O)2]2+ cations offer a non-centrosymmetric environment to align the polar [MO x F6–x ]2– anions. However, only the [MoO2F4]2– anion matches with its environment and is fully aligned. In the future, the “lock and key” model could also be of importance to understand, engineer, and optimize the polarity of new materials.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

The "lock and key" model offers a good description of the polar arrangement of acentric BBUs in infinite chains. The lock (the environment of acentric BBU) must be designed properly to induce the alignment of the net dipole moment, and the key (the polar BBU) must match with the lock to optimize the alignment of the polar BBUs. A non-centrosymmetric environment for polar BBUs, suitable for the alignment of the net dipole moments, can be designed using an additional acentric unit. In the mixed metal oxide fluorides M'(2,2'-bpy)(H2O)2MO x F6-x  [M'/M = Cu/Ti, Cu/V, Cu/Nb, Cu/Mo, Zn/Mo, and Zn/W] reported in this paper, the acentric [M'(2,2'-bpy)(H2O)2]2+ cations offer a non-centrosymmetric environment to align the polar [MO x F6-x ]2- anions. However, only the [MoO2F4]2- anion matches with its environment and is fully aligned. In the future, the "lock and key" model could also be of importance to understand, engineer, and optimize the polarity of new materials.

cln_elements.content:
Single crystals of compounds 1–6 have been synthesized by the hydrothermal method. All reagents were heat-sealed in a Teflon pouch and placed in a 125 mL Parr autoclave with a backfill of 45 mL of distilled water. The autoclave was heated to 150 °C for 24 h and slowly cooled to room temperature at 6 °C/h. The single crystals were recovered by filtration.

Cu(2,2′-bpy)(H2O)2TiF6 single crystals (1) were synthesized by adding 1.477 × 10–3 mol (0.118 g) of TiO2, 1.69 × 10–3 mol (0.134 g) of CuO, 2.56 × 10–3 mol (0.400 g) of 2,2′-bipyridyl, 5.5 × 10–3 mol (0.1 mL) of H2O, and 28.42 × 10–3 mol (1.16 g) of 48% HF to a Teflon pouch. Single crystals were recovered by vacuum filtration in air in a 60% yield based on Ti.

Cu(2,2′-bpy)(H2O)2VOF5 single crystals (2) were synthesized by adding 0.746 × 10–3 mol (0.136 g) of V2O5, 1.69 × 10–3 mol (0.134 g) of CuO, 2.56 × 10–3 mol (0.400 g) of 2,2′-bipyridyl, 5.5 × 10–3 mol (0.1 mL) of H2O, and 28.42 × 10–3 mol (1.16 g) of 48% HF to a Teflon pouch. Single crystals were recovered by vacuum filtration in air in a 46% yield based on V.

Cu(2,2′-bpy)(H2O)2NbOF5 single crystals (3) were synthesized by adding 0.740 × 10–3 mol (0.196 g) of Nb2O5, 1.69 × 10–3 mol (0.134 g) of CuO, 2.56 × 10–3 mol (0.400 g) of 2,2′-bipyridyl, 5.5 × 10–3 mol (0.1 mL) of H2O, and 28.42 × 10–3 mol (1.16 g) of 48% HF to a Teflon pouch. Single crystals were recovered by vacuum filtration in air in a 65% yield based on Nb.

Cu(2,2′-bpy)(H2O)2MoO2F4 single crystals (4) were synthesized by adding 1.687 × 10–3 mol (0.243 g) of MoO3, 1.69 × 10–3 mol (0.134 g) of CuO, 2.56 × 10–3 mol (0.400 g) of 2,2′-bipyridyl, 5.5 × 10–3 mol (0.1 mL) of H2O, and 28.42 × 10–3 mol (1.16 g) of 48% HF to a Teflon pouch. Single crystals were recovered by vacuum filtration in air in a 30% yield based on Mo.

Zn(2,2′-bpy)(H2O)2MoO2F4 single crystals (5) were synthesized by adding 1.687 × 10–3 mol (0.243 g) of MoO3, 1.69 × 10–3 mol (0.137 g) of ZnO, 2.56 × 10–3 mol (0.400 g) of 2,2′-bipyridyl, 5.5 × 10–3 mol (0.1 mL) of H2O, and 28.42 × 10–3 mol (1.16 g) of 48% HF to a Teflon pouch. Single crystals were recovered by vacuum filtration in air in a 48% yield based on Mo.

Zn(2,2′-bpy)(H2O)2WO2F4 single crystals (6) were synthesized by adding 1.680 × 10–3 mol (0.389 g) of MoO3, 1.69 × 10–3 mol (0.137 g) of ZnO, 2.56 × 10–3 mol (0.400 g) of 2,2′-bipyridyl, 5.5 × 10–3 mol (0.1 mL) of H2O, and 28.42 × 10–3 mol (1.16 g) of 48% HF to a Teflon pouch. Single crystals were recovered by vacuum filtration in air in a 70% yield based on W.

cln_elements.content: Design of mixed metal, nonpolar (a) linear chains, (b) zigzag chains, and (c) helical chains (L = organic ligand).
cln_elements.clean_text: 1  Design of mixed metal, nonpolar (a) linear chains, (b) zigzag chains, and (c) helical chains (L = organic ligand).

cln_elements.content: Strategy to align the polar anions along the chains by creating acentric LTM cations.
cln_elements.clean_text: 2  Strategy to align the polar anions along the chains by creating acentric LTM cations.

cln_elements.content: Representation of the (a) alignment of polar units AB in polar chain, (b) anti-alignment of polar units AB in nonpolar chain, (c) alignment of polar units AB and acentric unit A′B′ in polar chain by interaction AB–A′B′, (d) alignment of polar units AB and acentric unit A′B′ in polar chain by interaction AB–B′A′, and (e) disordering of polar units AB in nonpolar chain, owing to the interaction with centrosymmetric unit.
cln_elements.clean_text: 3  Representation of the (a) alignment of polar units AB in polar chain, (b) anti-alignment of polar units AB in nonpolar chain, (c) alignment of polar units AB and acentric unit A'B' in polar chain by interaction AB-A'B', (d) alignment of polar units AB and acentric unit A'B' in polar chain by interaction AB-B'A', and (e) disordering of polar units AB in nonpolar chain, owing to the interaction with centrosymmetric unit.

cln_elements.content: Structural criterion C for [MOF5]2– and [MO2F4]2– anions with different orientational disorder.
cln_elements.clean_text: 4  Structural criterion C for [MOF5]2- and [MO2F4]2- anions with different orientational disorder.

cln_elements.content: Identification of the ligand sites according to their nucleophilicity (Nw, weakest nucleophilicity; Nm, moderate nucleophilicity; and Ns, strongest nucleophilicity) in (a) chains of compound 1 with LTM = Cu (J–T = Jahn–Teller distortion) and (b) chains of hypothetical compound with LTM = Zn.
cln_elements.clean_text: 5  Identification of the ligand sites according to their nucleophilicity (Nw, weakest nucleophilicity; Nm, moderate nucleophilicity; and Ns, strongest nucleophilicity) in (a) chains of compound 1 with LTM = Cu (J-T = Jahn-Teller distortion) and (b) chains of hypothetical compound with LTM = Zn.

cln_elements.content: “Lock and key” representation of (a) compounds 2–4 with LTM = Cu and (b) compounds 5 and 6 with LTM = Zn. The alignment of the net dipole moment is optimized in the case of matching between the key (the polar anion) and the lock (its environment).
cln_elements.clean_text: 6  "Lock and key" representation of (a) compounds 2-4 with LTM = Cu and (b) compounds 5 and 6 with LTM = Zn. The alignment of the net dipole moment is optimized in the case of matching between the key (the polar anion) and the lock (its environment).

metadata.title:
Alignment of Acentric Units in Infinite Chains: A
“Lock and Key” Model
